messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] pondering this tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Peter, Interesting observation.  I don t think I ve seen nunome on Tibetan guards either, but I can t claim to have looked at many.  Are they typically
messages.messageBody:
Peter,
Interesting observation. I don't think I've seen nunome on Tibetan guards either, but I can't claim to have looked at many. Are they typically multi-plate construction?

It's at: http://pictures.care2.com/view/1/743171541 photo's 1 & 2.

Come to think of it I've seen Chinese guards with a square-profile cup shape. I don't think that they had a Japanese-shaped nakago ana or marks from seppa wear, though.

The rectangular pattern on the seppa dai and the style of nunome on the rim seem like typical Hizen traits. Of course they were working with foreign styles.

Jim




I looked at this guard when it was first mentioned. At that time, it seemed
very much like the dished guards seen on Tibetan swords, altho the nunome
zogan struck me as problematical. Could some please post the URL, I'd like
to take another look. Thanks

Peter Bleed
Associate Dean
College of Arts and Sciences
1223 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0312

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] pondering this tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, My best guess is that maybe it was easier to raise the rim from a thin sheet and the second sheet w/o cup rim was added for extra thickness.    ?
messages.messageBody:
Richard,
My best guess is that maybe it was easier to raise the rim from a thin sheet and the second sheet w/o cup rim was added for extra thickness. ?

Laminations aside, I have seen both flat cup guards like this and ones that are hemispherical like some European guards. Oddly any of these that I've seen mounted or with hitsuana have had the convex side toward the tsuka, in the opposite orientation of a European guard.

Jim



Hi Jim and Gordon, this is the reply from the owner

It's rather like a saucer. Flat on the other side, with the rim turned up. No detail at all on this side.

Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] pondering this tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim and Gordon, this is the reply from the owner It s rather like a saucer. Flat on the other side, with the rim turned up. No detail at all on this side.

Hi Jim and Gordon, this is the reply from the owner

It's rather like a saucer. Flat on the other side, with the rim turned up. No detail at all on this side.

Rich


Richard,
It's one of the nanban types. That style with the cupped shape and nunome
zogon is often labeled Hizen. I don't recall seeing one made with two-layer
construction like that, though. Does the other plate just cover the flat
area, or does it follow the cup all of the way to the rim?

Jim

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] pondering this tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, Interestingly, when I looked I thought Namban too. Very odd looking piece. Certainly has the color and design quality one expects from Namban. Gorodn
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim,

Interestingly, when I looked I thought Namban too. Very odd looking piece.
Certainly has the color and design quality one expects from Namban.

Gorodn
-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Wednesday, July 16, 2003 5:38 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] pondering this tsuba


Richard,
It's one of the nanban types. That style with the cupped shape and nunome
zogon is often labeled Hizen. I don't recall seeing one made with two-layer
construction like that, though. Does the other plate just cover the flat
area, or does it follow the cup all of the way to the rim?

Jim



greetings all, I lifted this of my message board,
http://pictures.care2.com/view/1/743171541 the owner is stumped and so
are the rest of us I think. This concerns images 1 & 2. Notice in the
tight shot of the nagako ana, three is obviously 2 plate of metal, I
thought I was looking at leather or something at first but it is
obviously iron. What would be the purpose of the, is it common/rare, he
was wondering if there is a known style/school/era for this piece.

cheers

Rich
